posts.name: SignalUser
posts.cooked:
We send in our groups (family / work) a lot of attachments.

Doesn´t make it sense to save the attachments automatically to the device?
Of course, only if the user wants it.

Due to my message limit of 250 pieces, I regularly lose pictures and videos because too many new messages have been received since the last manual download.

Furthermore, the app is getting bigger, especially with older smartphones can lost performence.

So its easy to fix this problem with automatic save attachment.

Control auto-download of received media based on attachment type and network

Remaining GitHub issues that can be closed because they are feature requests

Storage | how to save Media into a accessible folder

posts.name: SignalUser
posts.cooked: I mean regular signal messages in groups (attachments). Not SMS oder MMS.

Yeah I don’t think we want to have any automatic function which takes encrypted data and saves it in unencrypted form to the device. If it is in Signal it should stay there unless some very specific and unique actions happen, i.e. a backup or the user explicitly selects to save/share data out of the app.

Instead I think it would be better to add a ‘save all media’ button to each thread to handle this case, which would save all attachments at once and save you some clicks.

Furthermore, you could increase your automatic message count deletion on your phone? This would give you more time to save attachments if desired. Or just leave everything in Signal and never export the media?

skulumani:

Instead I think it would be better to add a ‘save all media’ button to each thread to handle this case, which would save all attachments at once and save you some clicks.

I guess you are talking about iOS?

On Android, this function (“Select all” + “Save to internal memory”) exists since version 4.27 (released October).

posts.cooked: I’m a little bit worried about that there could be people who’d turn it on out of habit (“like on WhatsApp”) and/or for convenience reasons, but eventually forget that they did so (and even worse: I don’t know either when sending them confidential media that shouldn’t hit the storage unencrypted). Getting to know afterwards might already be to late. I think here security aspects should be prioritized over convenience…

posts.name: Meteor0id
posts.cooked:
Might show an icon on every image preview in chat to indicate “has been saved to phone (insecure)”
I am not sure that would be a good solution.

But I do agree with @PiCob that the user needs to be protected from himself better here, this is indeed a security risk.

I agree with all who say it would not be prudent or welcome to have ‘save all media automatically on device’ as a default or even an option. If a user wants to save something or share it outside of Signal they can do that with a particular picture/video, but having all media stay in Signal by default eliminates the security risk of ‘setting and forgetting’.

posts.name: Germain
posts.cooked:
Nearly all other chat apps allow some form of auto-save to camera roll/image gallery of received images and videos. Matching this functionality in Signal would be great option, preferably on a per-conversation/per-contact basis.

====

Note: This is a feature request initiated here Feature Request: Option to auto-save received images/video to camera roll · Issue #1567 · signalapp/Signal-iOS · GitHub but could not find anything equivalent on the forum.

link_counts.title: Feature Request: Option to auto-save received images/video to camera roll · Issue #1567 · signalapp/Signal-iOS · GitHub

posts.cooked: I think it is very important to have a auto save option.

Auto-save defeats the security of the app. I’m not sure what features the iOS app has, but it’s very easy to save specific images you want to keep on the Android app, and you can even go into “All Media” for a conversation to quickly select multiple images you want to save.
I don’t want that…

Abolouay:

I think it is very important to have a auto save option.

anon57494327:

I don’t want that…

… because?!

See: if you have (not-yet-mentioned) arguments for your opinion (I assume, there are arguments), naming those here would improve the discussion. If you just want to show your support for this feature (or a mentioned reason against / in favor of it), please use the like button of the corresponding post (as suggested in the community guidelines: “Rather than posting “+1” or “Agreed”, use the Like button.”). Just saying “I want it” or “I don’t want it” doesn’t really contribute to the discussion at all. Thanks!

PiCob:

… because?!

For me it’s a privacy issue because all other apps can access that media files.

posts.name: Meteor0id
posts.cooked:
anon57494327:

For me it’s a privacy issue because all other apps can access that media files.

And is it not unthinkable that other apps start scanning your media files as soon as you allow them to, and start making copies or generating thumbnails or start fingerprinting those files. The scenario of this happening is quite realistic.

We should make sure the user is discouraged to store his media and files outside of Signals encryption. Automatic saving (in unecrypted form) contradicts the discouraging. Yes, even if auto saving is optional. We should not provide users with a way to mass compromise his encrypted media and files. It should remain a conscious choice for small amounts of files.

After a new Signal user asked me, why they don’t see images in their album (like with other messenger transfered images), I now understand what OP meant.

The way Signal works now, is the correct way, because data is encapsulated inside the Signal app and other applications do not have access to data inside.

You don’t really know what can Google services or other apps that have Storage Permission access or even what they send (majority of apps are radio noisy as fu*k). Maybe they can send even thumbnails of images somewhere. And that is something consumers should be aware of.

Average Joe who wasn’t in a computer sciences school or hasn’t even took time to learn anything about consciously thinking at every step what their (inter)actions with a computer affect the process. They won’t even think about getting a firewall and checking what their apps are communicating with (or trying to). It is too much work for them.

There really is a huge market for courses about safe use of technology.

I regularly see people using these things without a slightest thought about how their actions reflect in reality or even basic understanding what is a folder and that an album they create inside the Gallery app is a folder etc.

It really makes my hair raise how majority is oblivious to basic computer skills and knowledge about them.

Such people are a gold mine for predatory data sucking companies.

Computers as such, should be radio silent unless user’s interaction requires to transceive something.

As file explorer I recommend Cx File Explorer and as gallery I recommend Camera Roll. Both of these applications are very useful, have tons of options and they are radio silent (which is important).

Majority of file explorer / gallery apps constantly call some AWS, Google or even frickin Facebook.

posts.name: Andy Keeves
posts.cooked:
I was fascinated to see discussion on safety and security of attached images. Yes, the default saving of encrypted attachments is safe.

If a user gets lots of pictures and the ELECT TO SAVE the images outside of the database it is their choice and it can already be done, albeit, one by one.

If one was to write code to fetch all images from the database and save them outside that too would be their choice. If it does not feel safe - don’t do it.

So, a switch in preferences that would allow OPTIONAL saving of MMS images certainly would be of no harm to those wishing to save family pictures, for example.

If saving images was such as security concern that it would detract from the app’s safety I suggest the app is already unsafe since I can save images now. The debate should not be about saving or not saving (a feature already implemented) but HOW it is implemented to make usability and function better while continuing to keep the encrypted database.

Cheers!

keevan:

So, a switch in preferences that would allow OPTIONAL saving of MMS images certainly would be of no harm to those wishing to save family pictures, for example.

I disagree, since such a switch means that all incoming images do automatically (and without review) hit the disk unencrypted on the receiver’s side - and the receiver doesn’t know beforehand whether or not sensitive media will arrive (plus the sender doesn’t know that the receiver has automatic saving enabled).

posts.name: Andy Keeves
posts.cooked:
I’m sorry, but that is just silly! First of all, if you have such a concern simply do not turn the switch on. Your problem is solved since functionality remains exactly as it is now. My problem is solved because I can turn such a switch on, should I wish to. This is called ‘options’ or not being locked into a single idea. Most good apps have lots of ‘options’ even though many use only the default settings. Makes for a tad bit more difficult code to write but a larger and more diverse customer base.

Secondly, such options could be applied to specific senders instead of globally. My daughter sends pictures of her children, not state secrets. And, should I be concerned about those children’s pictures getting out - I will not turn the switch on. Not complicated.

Thirdly, the concerns are lowered (though not eliminated) with encrypted devices. Why would someone be running an Android device without encryption anyway?

Last but not least, if I can save one picture manually why can I not save 5 (or 10 or whatever number) manually - at the same time? The number of keystrokes required to save 10 pictures is simply overbearing when one could use a multi-select instead. Thus, even a manual save would be much less painless if any number of images could be tagged and saved at once.

Cheers!

posts.name: Meteor0id
posts.cooked:
I am not in favor of automatically compromising some security feature. (So I am not in favor of offering the quick solution of automatically saving images on the device). I think there is a degree in which Signal should prevent users from making dumb choices, simply by not offering them.

But that said, I am against automated saving on the device. When a user manually and consciously takes the decision every time he preforms that action, sure, by all means, do your thing.

So this right here seems like a reasonable compromise:

keevan:

why can I not save 5 (or 10 or whatever number) manually - at the same time ?

keevan:

I’m sorry, but that is just silly! First of all, if you have such a concern simply do not turn the switch on . Your problem is solved since functionality remains exactly as it is now.

Apparently you didn’t really (want to?) understand what I wrote (and by the way: please stay polite - no need to call other people’s opinions stupid/silly or behave as if nobody knew what an option is, especially not if you didn’t read exactly). To be more precise: turning a switch on or off on my phone (the sender) doesn’t prevent the receiver of my sensitive media from automatically saving if he/she turns the switch on (and neither do I have control over the receiver’s setting nor do I know how it is set). Apart from that, even with a switch the receiver doesn’t know beforehand whether or not sensitive media will arrive (which he/she might not want to touch the disk).

keevan:

Last but not least, if I can save one picture manually why can I not save 5 (or 10 or whatever number) manually - at the same time ?

Don’t know your OS, but I assume you’re running iOS (since on Android this is already possible). Sure, it should be possible with the iOS app as well.
